current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To improve the circulation of $1 coins, to remove barrier
		  to the circulation of such coins, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban
			 Affairs

short-title.#text:
Currency Optimization, Innovation, and
			 National Savings Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Improving
			 circulation and removing barriers to circulation of $1 coins

Duties of the
			 Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

text.#text:
Not later than 6
			 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Board of Governors of the
			 Federal Reserve System shall sequester all $1 coins bearing the design common
			 to those $1 coins minted and issued from 1979–1981 and again in 1999.

text.#text: The ninth proviso of

header.#text:
Saving taxpayers
			 funds by transitioning to the use of $1 coins

text.#text:
It is the policy of the United States that after $1 coins
			 achieve sufficient market penetration such that consumers and retailers are
			 comfortable using $1 coins and are able to obtain adequate supplies of $1
			 coins, $1 coins should replace $1 Federal Reserve notes as the only $1 monetary
			 unit issued and circulated by the

Federal Reserve
			 banks may continue to place into circulation $1 Federal Reserve notes until the
			 earlier of—

header.#text:
Deadline for
			 placing $1 Federal Reserve notes into circulation

text.#text:
the date on which
			 the number of $1 coins placed into circulation after the date of the enactment
			 of this Act exceeds 600,000,000 annually; or

the date that is 4
			 years after the date of the enactment of this Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, a Federal
			 Reserve bank may not order additional $1 Federal Reserve notes but may, for a
			 period of one year, continue to place into circulation $1 Federal Reserve notes
			 on hand or those deposited with it, except for notes described in
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Currency Optimization, Innovation, and National Savings Act/s:3/ss:b
Currency Optimization, Innovation, and National Savings Act/s:3/ss:d

text.#text: After the date referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, a
			 Federal Reserve bank shall continue to remove unfit currency from circulation,
			 and shall continue to destroy such currency.

text.#text: Notwithstanding

Notwithstanding any other subsection of this
			 section, $1 Federal Reserve notes are legal tender in the United States for all
			 debts, public and private, public charges, taxes, and duties, regardless of the
			 date of printing or issue.
